fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (two-sided) identity for a binary operation on X is an element e\in X such that for all x\in X, ex = xe = x. If only one identity holds, this is a left- or right-identity, as appropriate.
A k-ary operaton on a set X is a function X^k\to X. We call k the arity of the operation.
A constant is a 0-ary operation, while a binary operation is a 2-ary operation.
A binary operation on X is associative if, for all a, b, c\in X, (ab)c = a(bc).
A binary operation on X is commutative if, for all a, b\in X, ab = ba.

A binary operation on X is (two-sidedly) cancellative if, for all a, b, c\in X, ab = ac \text { implies } b = c \quad \text { and }\quad ba = ca \text { implies } b = c. If only one implication holds, this is called left- or right-cancellative, as appropriate.
If the operation additionally has an identity e, then cancellability is equivalent to the statement that, for any x\in X, x has a (two-sided) inverse, i.e. an element y\in X such that xy=yx=e.
A (two-sided) identity for a binary operation on X is an element e\in X such that for all x\in X, ex = xe = x. If only one identity holds, this is a left- or right-identity, as appropriate.

Let X be equipped with two binary operations + and \cdot . Then \cdot (two-sidedly) distributes over + if, for all a,b,c \in X, a\cdot (b + c) = a\cdot b + a\cdot c\quad \text { and }\quad (b + c)\cdot a = b\cdot a + c\cdot a. If this identity holds only on one side, it is called left- or right-distributivity, as appropriate.
We say a group-like structure is a structure with a single binary operation that satisfies some subset of associativity, commutativity, cancellability, and the existence of an identity.
A magma is a set together with a binary operation.
A semigroup is an associative magma.
A monoid is a semigroup with unit, that is, a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation.
A group is a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation and inverses.
An abelian group is a commutative group. Its operation is generally written additively, a + b.
A ring is an abelian group (R, +) together with a monoid (R, \cdot ) satisfying the (two-sided) distributive law r(s + t) = rs + rt\quad \text {and}\quad (s + t)r = sr + tr.
A ring homomorphism is an additive homomorphism that preserves multiplication and the unit; the category of rings Ring is the category of rings and ring homomorphisms.

A binary operation on X is (two-sidedly) cancellative if, for all a, b, c\in X, ab = ac \text { implies } b = c \quad \text { and }\quad ba = ca \text { implies } b = c. If only one implication holds, this is called left- or right-cancellative, as appropriate.
If the operation additionally has an identity e, then cancellability is equivalent to the statement that, for any x\in X, x has a (two-sided) inverse, i.e. an element y\in X such that xy=yx=e.
A group is a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation and inverses.
A monoid is a semigroup with unit, that is, a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
A k-ary operaton on a set X is a function X^k\to X. We call k the arity of the operation.
A constant is a 0-ary operation, while a binary operation is a 2-ary operation.
A binary operation on X is associative if, for all a, b, c\in X, (ab)c = a(bc).
A binary operation on X is commutative if, for all a, b\in X, ab = ba.

A binary operation on X is (two-sidedly) cancellative if, for all a, b, c\in X, ab = ac \text { implies } b = c \quad \text { and }\quad ba = ca \text { implies } b = c. If only one implication holds, this is called left- or right-cancellative, as appropriate.
If the operation additionally has an identity e, then cancellability is equivalent to the statement that, for any x\in X, x has a (two-sided) inverse, i.e. an element y\in X such that xy=yx=e.
A (two-sided) identity for a binary operation on X is an element e\in X such that for all x\in X, ex = xe = x. If only one identity holds, this is a left- or right-identity, as appropriate.

Let X be equipped with two binary operations + and \cdot . Then \cdot (two-sidedly) distributes over + if, for all a,b,c \in X, a\cdot (b + c) = a\cdot b + a\cdot c\quad \text { and }\quad (b + c)\cdot a = b\cdot a + c\cdot a. If this identity holds only on one side, it is called left- or right-distributivity, as appropriate.
We say a group-like structure is a structure with a single binary operation that satisfies some subset of associativity, commutativity, cancellability, and the existence of an identity.
A magma is a set together with a binary operation.
A semigroup is an associative magma.
A monoid is a semigroup with unit, that is, a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation.
A group is a set equipped with an associative, unital binary operation and inverses.
An abelian group is a commutative group. Its operation is generally written additively, a + b.
A ring is an abelian group (R, +) together with a monoid (R, \cdot ) satisfying the (two-sided) distributive law r(s + t) = rs + rt\quad \text {and}\quad (s + t)r = sr + tr.
A ring homomorphism is an additive homomorphism that preserves multiplication and the unit; the category of rings Ring is the category of rings and ring homomorphisms.
A k-ary operaton on a set X is a function X^k\to X. We call k the arity of the operation.
A constant is a 0-ary operation, while a binary operation is a 2-ary operation.
